articles.title: SEPTEMBER IN THE YEAR 1978
articles.summary: This document outlines a busy schedule of astronomical events and club activities for September 1978, with some events in late August and early October. It details star parties at various locations like Fremont Peak and Sanborn Canyon, indoor star parties at the Los Gatos Red Cross, and general meetings featuring speakers on topics like space settlements and energy alternatives. Additionally, it lists Board of Directors meetings for both the San Jose Astronomical Association and the AANC, and announces a lunar graze occultation expedition.

articles.title: Conference at Cal Poly
articles.summary: A conference at Cal Poly saw 240-250 attendees, featuring diverse talks from southern skies to astrology, including a banquet speech by Ashley McDermott on the limits of knowledge in astronomy and discussions about an upcoming solar eclipse. Jackson Carle received the G. Bruce Blair Award, and a star party was held despite poor seeing. The report also briefly notes an August 11th Board meeting where club publicity and a phone book listing were discussed.

articles.title: ADS
articles.summary: This classifieds section lists a used 8" Newtonian telescope with accessories for sale by Brad Carlson. Additionally, L. K. Lantz is seeking to purchase a used 5-6" Cassegrainian or Maksutov telescope.

articles.title: ADS
articles.summary: This document contains classified advertisements for astronomical equipment. Items for sale include a 10-inch Newtonian f/8 Cave Model C Deluxe telescope and an award-winning 10-inch f/6 telescope with a guide scope and dual-axis electronic controls, suitable for deep-sky photography. There is also an ad seeking a portable pier or tripod mounting for an 8-inch Newtonian or Ritchey-Chrétien telescope.

articles.title: BLURBS
articles.summary: This month's Bulletin marks the editor's one-year anniversary, prompting a request for member feedback and ideas to improve future issues. The article also shares personal updates on members like John Rhodes' recovery and birthday celebrations for Denni Medlock and Cathy Pinheiro, alongside announcements for upcoming events, including a San Mateo club meeting and an AANC board meeting/indoor star party. It concludes with a humorous observation about many club members also being tropical fish enthusiasts.

articles.title: GRAZE INFORMATION
articles.summary: This document details an upcoming lunar graze occultation of a magnitude 6.2 double star event scheduled for September 23-24, 1978, in the Central Valley west of Fresno, California. Observers are given specific directions, timing (central graze at 1:25 AM PDT), and communication details via CB radio, with a special note about the separate occultation of the double star components. Participants are advised to arrive early and call for weather updates.

articles.title: Many handy numbers and neat stuff
articles.summary: This document presents a detailed collection of astronomical data, including various lunar angles like graze position, vertex, cusp, and Watts angles, alongside twilight and moonrise times. It also lists celestial coordinates (RA and Declination) for a star and the Moon, the star's magnitude and spectrum (A5), Moon elevation, azimuth, and illumination, all pertaining to an observation in the constellation Orion. The document likely serves as an ephemeris for a specific lunar observation event.

articles.title: A Sheep in Wolf's Clothing
articles.summary: This article profiles Wolfgang Hanisch, a high school oceanography and photography teacher who developed a deep passion for astronomy after his class inquiries led him to research the cosmos. Inspired by the idea that anyone can be an astronomer, Wolf now enjoys the ever-changing, mysterious, and romantic aspects of the universe, finding new friends through his involvement. He plans to be more active in his astronomy club, pursue more observing and astrophotography, and eventually build his own telescope, while also considering a career change to photography.

articles.title: Messier Marathon
articles.summary: This article describes the 'Messier Marathon,' an astronomical challenge to observe nearly all 107 visible Messier objects in a single night from dusk to dawn. The optimal period for this event is late March through mid-April, with specific dates suggested for 1979 being March 30 or 31, leveraging a new moon. The author, Don Machholz, invites participants to an observing site at Loma Prieta and encourages prior familiarization with the objects.

articles.title: Comet Comments
articles.summary: This article discusses Comet Ashbrook-Jackson (1977g), identifying it as the brightest known comet at 11-12 magnitude and provides an ephemeris for its observation from August to September 1978. It also briefly mentions Edgar Everhart's 1967 study on comet discoveries, noting the consistent rate of visual discoveries and the significant role of amateur astronomers in finding new comets.

articles.title: Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects - Chart V, continued
articles.summary: This document, a continuation of "Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects - Chart V," provides a detailed observational guide for various deep-sky objects, including nebulae, open clusters, and galaxies. For each entry, it lists NGC/IC numbers, coordinates, magnitudes, sizes, types, distances, and offers specific recommendations for optimal viewing with telescopes or binoculars under different power settings and sky conditions. The guide includes tips for challenging objects and highlights notable features.

articles.title: RATTLEY RATTLES
articles.summary: SJAA President David V. Rodrigues outlines his goals for his second term, focusing on increasing club activity and participation after a successful period of membership growth under the previous president. The message details several upcoming events, including an AANC board meeting, a Red Cross Indoor Star Party, a grazing occultation expedition, and the September club meeting featuring a "Chart Talk" and a general slide night. It also provides a reminder about the 1979 solar eclipse and offers updates on two deep-sky objects.

articles.title: Cathy Pinheiro
articles.summary: Cathy Pinheiro presents this month's list of astronomical books, pamphlets, and magazines available to club members, providing contact details for further information. The article also includes a "Question of the Month" section where members offer humorous answers to "What does the Black Hole look like?" and announces the topic for the following month.

articles.title: Report of August 12 General Meeting
articles.summary: The article reports on the August 12 General Meeting, where President Gerry Rattley announced John Rhodes' successful surgery, upcoming club events (San Mateo meeting, AANC board meeting, lunar graze), and Pete Manly's grant proposal for a television camera. The meeting also featured a program on Stonehenge. Additionally, the article recounts a refreshingly intimate and successful star party at Freakie Peak on August 4-5, which contrasted positively with past overcrowded events and fostered hope for more focused observing gatherings.

articles.title: C OF FREMONT NEAR SOUTH
articles.summary: This document provides a set of fragmented and somewhat unclear directions to a location near Fremont, potentially involving a trail or camp in the vicinity of Gilroy. It outlines navigational steps, including specific turns from San Jose, following Placer Canyon, and identifying landmarks like a gate and a building on a ridge. The text appears to be a rough guide for an outdoor destination.

articles.title: MAP
articles.summary: This document contains a detailed, hand-drawn map illustrating various geographical features, trails, and specific locations. It marks routes and points of interest such as Anderson Lake, Coyote Lake, Fremont Peak State Park, and various roads and districts like Gill Road and National Water District.

articles.title: IF YOU CAN'T UNDERSTAND DIRECTIONS TO GERRY'S GRAND DIRECTIONS WILL TRY TO HELP YOU.
articles.summary: This document provides somewhat informal and potentially confusing directions to two locations: the Los Gatos Red Cross Building and Sanborn Skyline County Park. It includes textual instructions with landmarks like Highway 17, Saratoga, and specific traffic lights, complemented by a hand-drawn map illustrating the routes and key points like the park and various roads. The title suggests it's a guide to help people find a specific event or gathering.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION, INC. - SEPTEMBER 1978
articles.summary: This document is a membership directory for the San Jose Astronomical Association, Inc. from September 1978. It lists members' names, addresses, cities, ZIP codes, and phone numbers, providing contact information for the association's members during that period.

articles.title: BULLETIN SUBSCRIBERS
articles.summary: This document includes a list of bulletin subscribers with their contact information, followed by a personal observing report from Penny Pinschmidt. She describes her enjoyable experience at a star party at Henry Coe on August 2nd, where she used a telescope for the first time by herself, and also mentions missing a crowded club star party at the same location on August 5th.

articles.title: EDITORIAL
articles.summary: This editorial challenges club members, especially those who are highly opinionated, to contribute guest editorials to the Bulletin. The editor expresses frustration that despite many members readily sharing their thoughts verbally, they are reluctant to put them in writing, contrasting this with the editor's regular contributions.
